title-group.article-title: Comparison of linear and non-linear controllers for active steering of vehicles in evasive manoeuvres

contrib-group.aff: Center for Intelligent Systems Research, The George Washington University, Ashburn, Virginia, USA

abstract.p: This paper presents different control approaches to perform an evasive collision avoidance manoeuvre using active steering. Linear and non-linear controllers to control the combined lateral and longitudinal motion of the vehicle using predefined trajectories are compared. A proportional–derivative controller, a linear quadratic regulator (LQR), and two different sliding-mode controllers (SMC) were developed. The second SMC model includes an additional velocity error term, which augments the model with a steering actuator term. The controllers were implemented on a bicycle model and a 17 degrees-of-freedom (DOF) vehicle model. The results showed that all controllers perform similarly in controlling the trajectory of the bicycle model. However, in implementation on the non-linear full vehicle dynamics model, the LQR and SMCs provided similar position tracking, but the two SMCs performed better in minimizing the yaw (directional) error at the end of the trajectory. However, at a higher velocity, SMC2 resulted in a more stable manoeuvre than SMC1.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: The automotive industry has implemented many advanced technologies in road vehicles during the past few years. Among those, active steering is implemented on some vehicles commercially in the form of lane-keeping systems [1]. Using steering control to perform an automated lane change manoeuvre has been the subject of many studies [2–6]. Both linear and non-linear controllers have been designed to perform this kind of manoeuvre [3, 5–8]. However, most of these controllers have been designed for sufficiently smooth manoeuvres in which tyre slip angles remain very small.

Simple proportional–derivative (PD) controllers that use only the lateral velocity of the vehicle are not as effective as controllers that use both lateral velocity and yaw angle to control the lateral dynamics of the vehicle [3, 9].

In references [5] to [7], sliding mode controllers were developed to perform automated lane change manoeuvres. To reduce tyre saturation, front steering is the most desirable approach for obstacle avoidance, and four-wheel steering has almost the same maximum actuator effort as front-wheel steering [10].

This paper examines a few new modelling and control system approaches. As indicated, most of the research on the control of the lateral motion of the vehicle has been done on lane change manoeuvres, which last several seconds [3, 11, 12]; however, in this study the control of the vehicle in performing severe manoeuvres was studied. In this paper, PD and linear quadratic regulator (LQR) controllers were developed using both direction error and lateral position error. Also, a sliding mode controller (SMC) was developed with two different sliding surfaces. The first SMC uses the direction error (yaw angle) and the lateral position error to define the sliding surface; this kind of error definition has been used by other researchers in the past but with somewhat different dynamic models. The second SMC uses a lateral velocity error (global coordinate) in addition to the previous terms. The new term gives the freedom to control steering angle and provide more realistic steering angle input by treating the steering angle as a state variable. The developed controllers are tried on two different simulation models of the vehicle, namely, a two degrees-of-freedom (DOF) bicycle model with large yaw angle assumptions, and a full vehicle dynamics model (using the CarSim software). The subject vehicle of this study is a Ford Taurus model 1992, and the tyre dynamics are based on the magic formula tyre model to increase the accuracy of the model. The validity and implementation advantages and disadvantages of the developed controllers will be discussed based on their results on a full vehicle body dynamics and sensors model.

This paper is organized as follows. After developing both a linear and non-linear model and choosing a desired trajectory to perform the evasive manoeuvre, first a set of PD controllers is developed using linear quadratic (LQ) methods by using the lateral velocity and the yaw rate of the vehicle. Second, a sliding mode controller is developed assuming some uncertainties in the system (SMC1). Third, the model is augmented with a steering actuator and a more suitable sliding mode controller is developed (SMC2). Finally, the above three controllers are implemented on a full vehicle model. In section 4, first the results of the three developed controllers based on the two DOF vehicle model will be presented under various manoeuvres, and then the results of using steering controllers on a full vehicle model (17 DOF) are presented. In section 5, the performance of the controllers both on the simple vehicle model and the full vehicle model are compared and the possibility of their implementation on a real vehicle is discussed.

sec.title: 2.3 Desired trajectory for vehicle manoeuvre
sec.p: Experimental tests have shown that experienced drivers can avoid an obstacle in 1.6 s at a speed of 16.67 m/s (60 km/h, 37.3 mile/h) [15]. There are sensor systems available in some commercial vehicles that can predict the possibility of accident up to 1.6 s in advance [16]. Therefore, the time to perform the manoeuvre was set to 1.6 s in all simulations. For the development of the LQR method and sliding mode controllers, a trapezoidal acceleration profile (TAP) [7] was chosen to represent the desired trajectory of the vehicle. As shown in Fig. 3, if the jerk input of the TAP is matched to the initial jerk of the 5th order polynomial, for the same desired final lateral displacement, the resultant acceleration profile has a lower peak than the 5th order polynomial. Consequently, with the same available maximum lateral acceleration (due to the coefficient of friction between tyre and road), TAP can accommodate more severe manoeuvres. sec.title: 3.3 Sliding model controller with linear tyre model (SMC1)
sec.p: The sliding mode controller is a robust controller in the presence of plant uncertainties and disturbances; however, this performance comes with the introduction of extremely high control activities. The basic idea of this type of controller is to direct the state space trajectories of the system to a sliding manifold called the sliding surface [22].

High control activity can excite the unmodelled dynamics of the system and introduce chattering problem [3]. The sliding mode controller has been used by different researchers to control the lateral dynamics of the vehicle [3, 5–7].

Here, first the sliding mode controller is developed using the position and yaw error (equation (18)), more or less similar to previous studies but with a slightly different sliding surface. sec.title: 3.6 Implementing controllers on a full vehicle dynamics model
sec.p: In this section, the developed controllers from sections 3.1 to 3.4 are used to control a 17-DOF vehicle dynamics model to evaluate the possibility of implementing these controllers on a real vehicle. To implement the controllers, the CarSim model was used as a plant (as shown in Fig. 4), and the steering angle is calculated by the developed controllers, which use the bicycle model of the vehicle, and feed the calculated steering input to the CarSim model. The steering angle is calculated by obtaining the design parameters such as velocity of the vehicle, its direction and position from the vehicle (Fig. 4). In the real world, these parameters are available either by direct measurement or by estimation.

caption.p: Implementing the controllers on the CarSim model

sec.p: To achieve the stated goals, after developing the vehicle model in CarSim, the scenarios to perform an evasive lane change manoeuvre were developed in the CarSim software and Simulink. Then, the controllers designed in the previous sections were developed in the Simulink environment. Finally, the controllers and the full vehicle model were integrated in the Simulink environment. sec.p: It is seen that the performance of all controllers in controlling the position error are very close to each other, with only minor differences. However, there are differences in controlling the end trajectory yaw angle. The trapezoidal trajectory is closely tracked by all controllers (Fig. 24) and the lateral accelerations produced by the controllers are similar (Fig. 25). Although the r.m.s. position error of the LQR controller (17.2 cm) is about the same as SMC1 (17.4 cm) and SMC2 (17.06 cm), it resulted in the highest front and rear wheels’ slip angles (Figs 26 and 27), and has the highest directional (yaw) error (2.3°) versus SMC1 (2.2°) and SMC2 (2.3°). These differences in yaw error are clearly observed in Fig. 29. This is further manifested as a higher required steering angle by the LQR (at 1 s; Fig. 28) as compared to other controllers. Although the sliding mode controllers generated similar steering angle inputs, the sliding mode with the augmented steering actuator resulted in a lower steering input than the other two controllers.

sec.title: 4.7 Full vehicle dynamics control (CarSim) results at other speeds
sec.p: In order to better evaluate the performance of the developed controllers on the vehicle, the simulations on the full vehicle dynamics model were performed at a lower speed (16.67 m/s (˜60 km/h)), and a higher speed (30 m/s (˜108 km/h)). Figure 30 shows the yaw angle of the vehicle with the controllers (LQR, SMC1, and SMC2) as well as the desired yaw angle. It can be seen that the yaw angle for all the controllers is higher than the desired value and they needed to regulate the yaw angle after changing the lane (at 1.6 s). Although overall the yaw angles were close to each other, SMC2 resulted in a more stable manoeuvre (less yaw angle in regulating phase). Again, the sliding mode controllers resulted in much lower steering angles than the LQR method. At 30 m/s, the two sliding mode controllers resulted in similar peaks with SMC1, producing slightly lower maximum peak, but more steering angle toward the end of the manoeuvre (as seen in Fig. 31). The r.m.s. error of position through the manoeuvre (until t = 1.6 s) was 20.4, 17.0, and 15.4 cm for LQR, SMC1, and SMC2. However, as it can be seen in Fig. 32, the SMC2 resulted in more position error than the other two at a velocity of 30 m/s after performing the manoeuvre.

sec.title: 5 Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: The implementation of linear and non-linear steering control crash avoidance systems was investigated. The performances of a LQR, a set of PD controllers, and sliding mode controllers to control a vehicle in a severe evasive manoeuvre were studied. Two different sliding mode controllers were modelled. In the first one, the steering angle input was the control input and in the second one the system was augmented with a steering actuator model to treat the steering angle as a state variable. It is important to note that the original system is not fully controllable, since there is only one control input (steering angle), but two variables that needed to be controlled (yaw angle and lateral position). Therefore, to design the LQR controller, the system was transformed into a new error coordinate system. This transformation was non-linear (as seen in equations (9) and (10)), which results in a controllable system. In the design of sliding mode controllers, the errors of direction (yaw) and position were summed together to form one error term, which was used to define the sliding surfaces. There is always a trade-off between achieving very low position error and yaw angle error. There are two weighting factors that contribute to this trade-off, which determine which variable will be penalized more than the other. This was done in combination with tuning the other control parameters in order to achieve both low position and low yaw errors, simultaneously. It should be noted that during the trajectory, the yaw error cannot become zero since the desired yaw angle is actually the sum of the yaw angle and the side slip angle. This variable can only become zero at the end of the trajectory.

In designing the sliding mode controllers, a linear tyre model was used to represent the dynamics of the vehicle. However, the kinematics relations were derived without the usual assumption of small yaw angle, since in performing severe manoeuvres, the yaw angle can be as high as 15–20°.

First, the performance of the controllers with the bicycle model, as the plant, was investigated. Based on this part, the LQR and the two sliding mode controllers were able to perform the evasive manoeuvre using the 2-DOF model, and the error from the desired path could become very small by tuning the gains. All designed controllers resulted in the same shape for steering input in following the desired trajectory (i.e. in avoiding the obstacle.)

Based on the results of this part, i.e. the bicycle model as the plant, both linear and non-linear controllers can be used to perform a manoeuvre if tyre slip angles remain in the linear region, and the choice of linear or non-linear controller depends on the control designer’s preference. This is especially helpful in less severe manoeuvres where tyre slip angles remain small. The purpose of this exercise was to develop a basic understanding of the problem, an initial model for the controllers, and a basis for comparison of the controllers for the more sophisticated full vehicle dynamics model as the plant.

In the second part, the developed controllers were implemented in a full vehicle dynamics model. The results showed that although the vehicle tracked the path and could perform the manoeuvre, it experienced higher slip and yaw angles throughout the trajectory as compared to the bicycle model. This inaccuracy could be due to non-linear tyre behaviour in higher slip angles and the effect of weight transfer due to roll angle in the evasive manoeuvre. The performances of all implemented controllers are very close to each other. The LQR controller resulted in the highest direction (yaw angle) error and the least position error. Also, using the LQR resulted in higher tyre slip angles and steering input than using the sliding mode controllers. Comparison of the sliding mode controllers showed their similar performance with slightly better performance for SMC2 at lower speeds. At a higher velocity (30 m/s), SMC2 showed a more stable performance than SMC1. However, it should be noted that this controller is more complicated with more required input, hence in real life implementation a higher complexity and cost is associated with it. Another result of this study is that the tyre slip angles are more than the predicted values using a linear tyre model and the single track vehicle model. Nevertheless, the developed controllers could keep the vehicle on the desired path.

The future research should address the present limitations and consider the following additions. In modelling, the weight shift and roll effect at severe manoeuvres, and the possibility of integrated braking and steering, should be considered. Further improvements could perhaps include models of the integrated safety systems such as traction and stability control, which may be functioning concurrently as the vehicle is being controlled for an evasive manoeuvre. The present results do not include any noise effects in sensors or other major disturbances to the vehicle. A full consideration of noise effects and the corresponding filtering methods would be a great addition to simulations, whereas in experimental research these effects need to be handled in the controller design implementations. Also, alternative methods of developing desired trajectories should be studied to perform the evasive manoeuvres with lower tyre slip angles, which results in a more stable manoeuvre.

sec.title: Vehicle parameters
sec.p: The parameters of a Ford Taurus (1992) were used in this study. These parameters were estimated based on the study by Heydinger et al. [24]. According to Heydinger et al., the track widths of the front and rear sides are 1.557 and 1.525 m; the height of centre of gravity is 0.550 m from the ground, and it is located at a distance of 0.959 m from the front axle; the wheelbase of the car is about 2.686 m. Also, the yaw and roll moment of inertias are 2765 and 541 kg m2, respectively. These values are shown in Table. 2. It was assumed that the vehicle with occupant had a minimum weight of 1500 kg.
